photos.monument: Memorial to Heroic Self Sacrifice London

photo.description: Set up by Victorian artist G.F. Watts in 1887 to mark Queen Victoria's Jubilee, the plaques commemorate "heroic acts of self-sacrifice" by Londoners who died saving others. He hoped that the project would continue and expand, but it never did.

photo.title: G.F. Watts's Memorial to Heroic Self Sacrifice, London, England

photo.description: The G F Watts Memorial in Postman's Park, Aldersgate, City of London. G F Watts was a painter who came up with the idea of a national memorial to the men, women and children who had lost their lives trying to save others. He made the proposal in 1887, the Golden Jubilee Year of Queen Victoria, but when nothing came of it he created his own memorial in Postman's Park. The memorial has plaques to 53 men, women and children, and the plaques detail the acts of heroism for which they gave their lives. It was unveiled in 1900 and was originally intended to house 120 plaques; but after Watts died in 1904 the addition of plaques became sporadic, ceasing after 1931. However, in 2009 one further plaque was added, honouring Leigh Pitts, a Reprographic Operator, who had drowned two years previously saving a child from a canal in Thamesmead. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tablets_on_the_Memorial_to_...
photo.title: "Heroic Self Sacrifice"

photo.description: Note the plaque to Leigh Pitt (top row). This was installed in 2007; the first for 78 years. It reads "Leigh Pitt, reprographic operator, aged 30, saved a drowning boy from the canal at Thamesmead, but sadly was unable to save himself. June 7th 2007"

photo.description: The G F Watts Memorial in Postman's Park, Aldersgate, City of London. G F Watts was a painter who came up with the idea of a national memorial to the men, women and children who had lost their lives trying to save others. He made the proposal in 1887, the Golden Jubilee Year of Queen Victoria, but when nothing came of it he created his own memorial in Postman's Park. The memorial has plaques to 53 men, women and children, and the plaques detail the acts of heroism for which they gave their lives. It was unveiled in 1900 and was originally intended to house 120 plaques; but after Watts died in 1904 the addition of plaques became sporadic, ceasing after 1931. However, in 2009 one further plaque was added, honouring Leigh Pitts, a Reprographic Operator, who had drowned two years previously saving a child from a canal in Thamesmead. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tablets_on_the_Memorial_to_...
photo.title: The G F Watts Memorial

photo.description: Plaque to PC Alfred Smith who was killed in an air raid in 1917. This is in Postmans Park, St Botolph's Aldersgate Churchyard, which is part of the Memorial to Heroic Self Sacrifice. This area was established by George Frederic Watts in 1900 as a memorial to "ordinary people" who died saving the lives of others and who otherwise might have been forgotten. A new plaque was added in 2009 after a break of some 78 years.
photo.title: Alfred Smith

photo.description: Inscription at the top reads: "To the honoured memory of our heroic comrades who fell in the Great War 1914-1919" "Subscribed for and erected by their colleagues of the Western Postal District as a lasting tribute to their self-sacrifice"
photo.tags: 051110 london fitzrovia warmemorial greatwar wwi royalmail
photo.title: Royal Mail War Memorial
